text: Northwest Florida Schools celebrating a great report card after the state releasing grades today.
speaker: SPEAKER_27

text: Both Okaloosa and Santa Rosa counties received A grades.
speaker: SPEAKER_27

text: Escambia County received a B for the fifth straight year.
speaker: SPEAKER_27

text: Escambia Public School Superintendent Keith Leonard says the latest report is the biggest improvement they have seen since 2011.
speaker: SPEAKER_25

text: And he spoke with our Brent Carney.
speaker: SPEAKER_25

text: And Brent, to what does he attribute this success?
speaker: SPEAKER_25

text: Yeah, Bob, the superintendent says the teachers and support staff worked extra hard last year, making sure students came prepared to class.
speaker: SPEAKER_32

text: Now, this year, grades for Escambia show 13 schools scored an A, 12 schools with a B, and 25 schools with a C. Now, last year, Escambia had eight schools that were given an F. Each improved to at least a C this year.
speaker: SPEAKER_32

text: Leonard says this year the state increased its standards, making it more difficult to achieve higher scores.
speaker: SPEAKER_32

text: The hard part will be this coming school year.
speaker: SPEAKER_28

text: You know, when you celebrate a victory, you know there's another game coming down the road.
speaker: SPEAKER_28

text: And this next school year gets started with our teachers returning on August 2nd.
speaker: SPEAKER_28

text: And then those 37,000... And Santa Rosa County and Okaloosa County schools celebrated their A ratings.

text: Santa Rosa County Superintendent Karen Barber thanked the teachers and staff for their hard work.

text: She touted that Santa Rosa schools are currently ranked 8th.
speaker: SPEAKER_32

text: eighth in the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_32

text: Now coming up a little bit later on tonight at 10, Warrington Prep Academy, which converted from a failing public school to a charter school, improved their scores as well.

text: The city of Milton is considering a proposal that would end its recycling program.
speaker: SPEAKER_25

text: City officials say the program is costing too much money.
speaker: SPEAKER_25

text: WEAR's Sade Ray joins us.
speaker: SPEAKER_27

text: Sade, there are two main factors driving that proposal.
speaker: SPEAKER_27

text: Bob, Sue, the assistant city manager says right now most of the recyclables are contaminated and go to the county landfill.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Or there's not enough buyers at the recycle site, which still sends it to the landfill.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: He says that isn't sustainable.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: The city of Milton started a recycling program in 2015.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Jimmy Messick is one of those customers.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: We were one of the original users of the recycling program when they started it.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I think that it's a good program.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Now, the city says the recycling program is getting too expensive.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: There's a proposal to end it.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: The program costs us approximately $150,000, but the cost of that is wrapped up in our sanitation budget, where the sanitation employees, the...
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: maintenance and repair of the vehicles, the tipping fees, which are about $9,000 just for the recycling, if it has to go to the landfill.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: The program, as far as the fee, only generates about $25,000 a year.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Ed Spears is Milton's assistant city manager.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: He says there hasn't been a load accepted into the recycling plant in more than two years.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: You are the greatest recycler in the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: You wash out your glass.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: You have the right kind of plastic.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: There's no food contamination.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: There's no other household garbage in there.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And it's collected, and your next-door neighbor or the neighbors down the street are using it for garbage, and it gets into that recycling truck by accident or simply we collect it.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: The load gets contaminated.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Another reason... Also, if we have a perfectly clean...
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: A set of recycling that we've collected from the community, everything's as it should be.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: If there's no buyer at the recycling facility for that, no paper buyer, no glass buyer, no plastic buyer, the whole load, as clean as it may be, goes to the landfill.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Spears says this adds work for the employees who have to go back to pick up those loads.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Messick says he's sad about the city recycling possibly ending, but can understand the argument.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: I'm a businessman, and if only 300 out of 11,000 are using it, and if they're not keeping their recycling clean, and most of it's going to the dump anyway, that's a negative against the program.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: City Council will talk about this proposal during their next fiscal budget meeting in September.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: If approved, the city will push out cancellation notices starting October.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Well, we are less than a month away from Florida's primary election.
speaker: SPEAKER_27

text: Escambia County tested its polling machines today for accuracy.
speaker: SPEAKER_27

text: A supervisor of elections invited WEAR News for a behind-the-scenes look at how it all works.
speaker: SPEAKER_25

text: And WEAR's Karis Harmon was there today for what they call logic and accuracy testing.
speaker: SPEAKER_25

text: Yeah, which was really like a mini-election, using test ballots to make sure the machines work correctly and are accurate.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Escambia County Supervisor of Elections Robert Bender is expecting heavy foot traffic to the polls.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: We expect high turnout for the general.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: We're probably going to look at about 35-40% for the primary.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: We did have our books closing so the last day for people to register or change their party has already passed.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: They can still request to vote by mail ballots.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: We've had about 26,000 ballots go out already.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: Which is why it was so important for the county to test its polling machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: We test the equipment that will be deployed for the election, making sure that it all works properly, but really to make sure that a vote for Robert gets counted as a vote for Robert.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: And so we run all the actual ballots that we'll be using on election day, and again, make sure that those votes are counted accurately.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: Going through all of the possible scenarios that could happen on election day, like if a ballot is duplicated or spoiled.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Deputy Supervisor of Election Sonia Daniel gave us an example using a test ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: This is a vote-by-mail ballot, and we know it's a vote-by-mail ballot because it has the V up at the top of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So this machine should reject that ballot because it was intended for vote-by-mail.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Ballots can go in head first, feet first, face up, face down, any way that's sideways.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: After the 2020 presidential election, there were some who believed votes were not accurate or not counted at all.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Bender says accuracy is of the utmost importance.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: The core of our democracy is what we do in elections, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: It's not connected to the Internet.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: They've just been connected to power to count those votes and then make sure that the results are accurately uploaded, consolidated, and then upload that master list to the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: So, again, this is almost like a mini-election that we're running.
speaker: SPEAKER_19

text: If you need a vote-by-mail ballot, your deadline to request one is August 8th.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Election day is August 20th.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: The polls are open from 7 a.m.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: till 7 p.m.
speaker: SPEAKER_07
